page.title: 15FARMING IN SADDLEWORTH
page.content: The area originally had scattered farmsteads with the traditional few animals to keep the owners relatively self-sufficient in milk, meat,etc. & to produce wool for spinning & weaving. As elsewhere in the country, farming developed into more of a specialised concern, and small 'dairy' farms came into being, amongst the more traditional sheep farms. Cattle were normally exclusively Shorthorns, but were replaced by Freisians in more recent times, so 'black & white' cows took the place of the 'reds' & 'roans' seen previously, as these are better milk-producers. Today, however, there are no longer any dairy cows to be seen, nor beef cattle. Farms are now solely sheep, with pasture divided into pens on lower accessible slopes & open grazing on the moors. Hay is produced, but there is no arable.
